addition_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
addition_assignment.name: Addition and assignment operator

subtraction_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
subtraction_assignment.name: Subtraction and assignment operator

multiplication_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
multiplication_assignment.name: Multiplication and assignment operator

division_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
division_assignment.name: Division and assignment operator

integer_division_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
integer_division_assignment.name: Integer division and assignment operator

modulus_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
modulus_assignment.name: Modulus and assignment operator

unary_plus.comment: There is only 1 unary operator in Haskell, unary minus
unary_plus.name: Unary plus operator

increment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not have an operator for incrementing in place.
increment.name: Increment (add 1) operator

decrement.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not have an operator for decrementing in place.
decrement.name: Decrement (subtract 1) operator

exponential.comment: There are 3 exponentiation operators in Haskell, for integers, floating point numbers, and rational numbers respectively
exponential.name: Exponential operator

less_than_or_equal_to.name: Less than or equal to operator

greater_than_or_equal_to.name: Greater than or equal to operator

null_coalescing.comment: Haskell does not have null references
null_coalescing.name: Null coalescing operator

is.comment: Haskell doesn't have a notion of identity/reference equality.
is.name: Is operator

is_not.comment: Haskell doesn't have a notion of identity/reference equality.
is_not.name: Is not operator

left_shift.comment: Haskell does not include bitwise operators by default, so you need to import the built-in Data.Bits module. This command shifts left if y is positive.
left_shift.name: Left shift bitwise operator

left_shift_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
left_shift_assignment.name: Left shift assignment operator

right_shift.comment: Haskell does not include bitwise operators by default, so you need to import the built-in Data.Bits module. This command shifts right if y is negative.
right_shift.name: Right shift bitwise operator

right_shift_assignment.comment: Haskell is a functional language, so it does not allow variable reassignment.
right_shift_assignment.name: Right shift assignment operator

null_forgiving.comment: Haskell does not have null references
null_forgiving.name: Null forgiving operator
